se_competencies.field_2: The competence to apply fundamental concepts of systems thinking in systems engineering and to understand the role of one's own system in its overall context.
se_competencies.field_5: An important component of the SE philosophy is the dissemination and use of systems thinking.  This is understood as a way of thinking that makes it possible to better understand and design complex systems and thus  create  a holistic understanding of the system [Gei19; HWF+19; WRF+15].
se_competencies.field_6: Approaches, methods and behavioral patterns of systems thinking are not widespread in the company.  There is no uniform understanding of systems. Individual principles of systems thinking are only used unconsciously, if at all.
se_competencies.field_7: Individuals use systems thinkingapproaches and methods  for their individual activities, such as increasing their individual understanding of the system. Basic activities such as system definition are carried out. A holistic view of the system does not take place.
se_competencies.field_8: Individual organizational units use approaches and methods of systems thinking for individual projects. Within these projects, systems are already viewed holistically so that  there is a good understanding of the system within the project team.
se_competencies.field_9: Systems thinking is practiced throughout the company. Essential terms of the system description are uniformly defined and known by all persons involved. Approaches and methods of this way of thinking are automatically used to view a system holistically and  increasesystem understanding.
se_competencies.field_10: In addition to the company-wide dissemination of the  approaches and methods associated withsystems thinking and a holistic understanding of systems, existing structures are continuously optimized and new approaches and methods are systematically integrated.

se_competencies.field_2: The ability to provide accurate data and information using cross-domain models to support technical understanding and decision-making.
se_competencies.field_5: The purpose ofmodel-based work is to support the activities for describing the system specification from the beginning of the conceptual architecture design through development to late phases of the system life cycle and to make decision-making processes and analyses available in a cost-effective and timely manner through a formalized application of the individual activities.
se_competencies.field_6: The system specification is not described on a model-based basis across all disciplines.
se_competencies.field_7: Individual aspects of the system specification are described using interdisciplinary models. Model-based work is not carried out on the basis of an explicit MBSE method.
se_competencies.field_8: Individual aspects of the system specification are supported by model-based work. Individual steps of an MBSE method are applied.
se_competencies.field_9: The description of the cross-disciplinary system specification is based on an MBSE method throughout. Guidelines and specifications define the form and characteristics in which the model-based system specification describes the system of interest.
se_competencies.field_10: The MBSE method is adapted to the specific needs of the company. The performance of the method is continuously optimized.

se_competencies.field_1: Consideration of system life cycle phases
se_competencies.field_2: The competence to consider the life cycles other than the operational phase in the system requirements, architectures and designs during the realization of a system.
se_competencies.field_3: Life cycles, business and company integration

se_competencies.field_2: The ability to place agile values / customer benefits at the center of development.
The ability to analyze the needs and expectations of stakeholders and use these to define requirements for a system.
se_competencies.field_3: Definition of requirements, business and company integration
se_competencies.field_5: Elicitation of requirements and their documentation and creation of corresponding requirements documents (as a structured set of requirements).
se_competencies.field_6:
There is no systematic and structured approach to eliciting and documenting requirements in the context of SE. 
Requirements are not documented or are documented in an unstructured manner.
se_competencies.field_7:
Document templates are available for documenting requirements. 
Isolated RE process and method modules are available and used.
se_competencies.field_8:
An RE process from the identification to the coordination of requirements exists, can be adapted to specific projects and is used for the most part.
Requirements are structured using systems thinking and documented using formal specifications.
Defined quality criteria for requirements and requirements documents are in place.
se_competencies.field_9:
The RE process is established throughout the company.
There are company-wide guidelines for structuring requirements using systems thinking. 
There is a security process and suitable measures for compliance with the quality criteria.
se_competencies.field_10:
A systematic and structured approach for determining and documenting requirements is in place and is followed throughout the company. Attribute scheme and integration into the RE process are clearly defined. Both internal and external parties use this attribute scheme. 
The RE approach is continuously optimized.

se_competencies.field_2: The competence to define the elements belonging to a system, their hierarchy, as well as their interfaces or their behavior and the associated derived requirements for the development of an implementable solution.
se_competencies.field_5: The (system) architecture comprises both the structure and the behavior of the system. It should fulfill a specific purpose, e.g. the description of the interaction of individual system elements. In the context of SE, the architecture is part of the system design. The architecture can be designed in a tool-supported, (semi-) formal, consistent and traceable manner [Alt12], [HWF+19]. The architecture design is supported by various methods.
se_competencies.field_6: The system is not  describedby an abstract and discipline-neutral architecture in the sense of SE.
se_competencies.field_7: Individual aspects of the system, such as the effective structure or the system states, are mainly described as required in accordance with an SE-compliant architecture. A methodical approach is not (consciously) pursued.
se_competencies.field_8: In individual departments, a methodical approach based on system thinking is used to systematically create individual aspects of the system architecture. The system architecture is designed on the basis of a defined thought model (e.g. RFLP) in order to leverage added value for product development with the architecture design.
se_competencies.field_9: The system architecture is described and analyzed company-wide, holistically from the perspective of the system and semi-formally (e.g. with SysML) using suitable methods. Viewpoints are defined for various purposes. The individual aspects are logically linked, e.g. between functional and physical architecture. Alternative solutions are considered.
se_competencies.field_10: The system architecture is formally described using a tool-supported, customized notation. The methods and the architecture design process are regularly evaluated and adapted.

se_competencies.field_2: The competence to integrate a set of system elements into a verifiable or validatable unit or to provide objective proof that a system fulfills the specified requirements (validation) or achieves its intended properties in the intended operating environment (validation).
se_competencies.field_5: Assessment of a product with regard to specific product properties (verification) and the usability of the product (validation)
se_competencies.field_6: No special expertise in V&V techniques available. There is no independent test instance in the company. Test procedures are not reproducible. Documentation is only rudimentary and with highly aggregated results.
se_competencies.field_7: Test procedures are partially reproducible. There is individual documentation and filing of V&V activities.
se_competencies.field_8: In some areas of the company, V&V procedures are documented in a standardized manner and made available centrally within these areas. The input parameters for the V&V procedures are often defined (e.g. in the form of requirements).
se_competencies.field_9:
V&V is an integral part of the development process and is carried out by an independent test instance. Deep, specialized V&V expertise is available. 
Standardized test procedures are predominantly used. 
Documentation is provided centrally and can be retrieved via project or component references, for example. The input parameters for the V&V procedures are defined.
se_competencies.field_10:
The documented knowledge can be found without context-specific prior knowledge. 
Wherever possible, V&V procedures and documentation are reused. The implementation and documentation of V&V activities are continuously optimized.

se_competencies.field_2: The competence to commission and operate the system and maintain its capabilities/functionalities over its lifetime.
The competence to apply methods that support the agile values in the project context and enable parallel work
The ability to organize oneself and manage tasks

The ability to communicate constructively, efficiently and consciously, including across domains, while recognizing and taking into account the feelings of other people and shaping relationships with colleagues and superiors sustainably and fairly.
se_competencies.field_3: Communication, ethics and professionalism, emotional intelligence

se_competencies.field_2: The ability to select suitable goals for a system or system element, to negotiate when necessary and to achieve them efficiently with a team and, if necessary, to guide team members in solving problems.
se_competencies.field_3: Technical leadership, support/ facilitation, team dynamics, negotiation, coaching and mentoring,

se_competencies.field_2: The competence to identify, plan, coordinate and adapt activities to deliver a satisfactory system, product or service with appropriate quality, finances and time.
se_competencies.field_3: Project management, finance, quality, planning, monitoring and control, concurrent development
se_competencies.field_5: In the SE philosophy, project management is closely linked to the system design of SE. For the successful development of systems, it is therefore important that SE is taken into account in organizational project planning and design and that individual activities of both areas are integrated with each other and corresponding role concepts and task descriptions are defined and delineated.
se_competencies.field_6: The coordination, design and planning of SE processes are not taken into account in project management. The activities and tasks of project management are not coordinated with those of SE.
se_competencies.field_7: In some SE pioneer projects, the coordination, design and planning of SE processes is carried out as part of project management. The activities and tasks of project management are not yet coordinated with those of SE throughout the company.
se_competencies.field_8: The coordination, design and planning of SE processes is organizationally anchored in project management. In practice, the activities and tasks of project management are not yet aligned with those of SE throughout the company.
se_competencies.field_9: The coordination, design and planning of SE processes are an integral, practiced part of project management. The activities and tasks of project management are coordinated with those of SE throughout the company.
se_competencies.field_10: The coordination, design and planning of SE processes are also continuously adapted to changing external conditions and systematically optimized as an integral part of project management.

se_competencies.field_2: The ability to identify, characterize and evaluate an objective set of alternatives in a structured and analytical manner, taking risks and opportunities into account
The ability to address all aspects of information for specific stakeholders in order to deliver the right information at the right time and with the right level of certainty.
The ability to harmonize system functions, performance and physical characteristics over the lifecycle and ensure consistency.

Process: Participants can understand why architecture models are relevant as inputs and outputs of the development process.
Method: Participants can read architecture models and extract relevant information from them.
Tool: Participants can view architecture models in a tool and comment/review them.

Development of functional, logical architecture
Synthesis - deriving the physical architecture from the logical architecture
Assignment of requirements to the architecture incl. derivation of requirements
Further architecture views (security, safety, etc.)
Images of alternatives, selection of alternatives
Criteria for architectures (comparative studies)
Interfaces and interactions between system elements, external systems and peripheral systems
Relationship between functional and phys. elements

Process: The participant understands the project assignment and can categorize project management in the context of systems engineering.
Methods: The participant can independently create the (project) plans relevant to him and generate corresponding status reports (with regard to Q-K-T).
Tool: The participant is able to carry out the planning in the respective tool.

Project goals and scope
PSP - Planning projects
Work packages

Table1: Competence
Definition
Know
Understanding
Apply
Mastery
Systemic thinking
The competence to apply fundamental concepts of systems thinking in systems engineering and to understand the role of one's own system in its overall context.
The participant knows the interrelationships of their system and the associated system boundaries.
The participant understands the interaction of the individual components that make up the system.
The participant is able to analyze his existing system and derive continuous improvements from it.
The participant is able to bring systems thinking into the company and inspire others to do the same.
System modeling and analysis
The ability to provide accurate data and information using cross-domain models to support technical understanding and decision-making.
Participants know the basis of modeling and its benefits.
Participants understand how models support their work. They are able to read models easily.
Participants are able to independently define their own system models for their relevant scope. They are able to distinguish between cross-domain and domain-specific models,
Participants can set guidelines for (necessary) models and write guidelines for good modeling.
Consideration of system life cycle phases
The competence to consider the life cycles other than the operational phase in the system requirements, architectures and designs during the realization of a system.
Participants know the life cycle phases of their system
The participant understands why and how all life cycle phases must be considered in the context of development.
The participant is able to identify, consider and evaluate all life cycle phases for the scopes relevant to him/her
The participant is able to evaluate concepts with regard to the consideration of all life cycle phases.
Agile thinking / customer benefit orientation
The ability to place agile values / customer benefits at the center of development.
The participant recognizes the basic principles of agile thinking.
The participant understands how agile thinking can be integrated into everyday working life
The participant is able to develop a system according to agile thinking and to put the customer benefit in the center of attention.
The participant is able to bring agile thinking into the company and inspire others to do the same.
Requirements management
The ability to analyze the needs and expectations of stakeholders and use these to define requirements for a system.

Process: Participants can differentiate between requirements, stakeholder requirements, system requirements and system element requirements. They know the importance of traceability and understand why tools are necessary for this,Method: The participants know the basic process of requirements management. This includes identifying, formulating, deriving and analyzing requirementsTool: The participants know that there is a tool for requirements management.

Process: Participants understand how requirements sources are identified, how requirements are derived and written. They know the different types and levels of requirementsMethod: Participants can read requirements documents or models (links etc.). They can read and understand context descriptions and interface specificationsTool: Participants can read in the requirements tool and view and comment/review requirements.

Process: Participants can independently identify sources of requirements, derive requirements from them, write them, document them in requirements documents or models, link them, derive them, analyze them.Method: Participants can independently document, link and analyze requirements documents or models. They can create and analyze context descriptions and interface specificationsTool: Participants can define, link and analyze requirements in a requirements tool.

Process: Participants are able to recognize shortcomings in the process and develop suggestions for improvement.Method: The participant is able to create context and interface descriptions and discuss these with stakeholders.Tool: Participants can use advanced functions in a requirements tool and create new templates, attributes and features.
System architecture design

The competence to define the elements belonging to a system, their hierarchy, as well as their interfaces or their behavior and the associated derived requirements for the development of an implementable solution.

Process: The participants know the purpose of architecture models. They can roughly categorize them in the development process.Method: The participants know that there is a dedicated methodology and modeling language for architecture modeling.Tool: Participants know that there is a dedicated tool for viewing and, if necessary, editing architecture models.

Process: Participants can understand why architecture models are relevant as inputs and outputs of the development process.Method: Participants can read architecture models and extract relevant information from them.Tool: Participants can view architecture models in a tool and comment on/review them.

Process: Participants know the relevant process steps for architecture models and know where their inputs come from in the development process and what outputs they produce.Method: Participants can create architecture models of average complexity. They are able to reproduce relevant information in accordance with the method and modeling language.Tool: Participants can create and analyze architecture models in a tool.

Process: Participants are able to recognize shortcomings in the process and develop suggestions for improvement.Method: Participants are able to create and manage models of high complexity. They can recognize shortcomings in the method or modeling language and develop suggestions for improvement.Tool: Participants can use advanced functions and create templates.
Integration, verification & validation

The competence to integrate a set of system elements into a verifiable or validatable unit or to provide objective proof that a system fulfills the specified requirements (validation) or achieves its intended properties in the intended operating environment (validation).
The participant knows the objectives of verification and validation and knows different types and procedures of V&V.
The participant can read and understand test plans, test cases and test results.
The participant can create test plans. They will be able to carry out and document tests and simulations.

The participant is able to set up a test strategy and a test plan independently and at an early stage. Based on the requirements and verification/validation criteria, they will be able to derive the necessary test cases. They will be able to orchestrate and document the tests and simulations.
Operation, service and maintenance
The competence to commission and operate the system and maintain its capabilities/functionalities over its lifetime.

The participants know the lines of the operation, service and maintenance phase. They know that these are already taken into account during development and that there are activities in the respective phase.
Participants understand how the operation, service and maintenance phases are taken into account in development. They will be able to name the activities that are necessary in the life cycle.
Participants understand how the operation, service and maintenance phases are taken into account in development. They will be able to process the phases and identify improvements for future projects.
Participants will be able to define the organizational processes for operations, service and maintenance,
Agile methodological competence
The competence to apply methods that support the agile values in the project context and enable parallel work
Method: The participant knows the agile values and the relevant agile methods
Method: The participant understands the basics of agile working methods and how agile methods can be applied in a development process.
Method: the participant can work in an agile environment. He is able to apply the necessary methods.
The participant can define and implement the relevant agile methods for a project. The participant is convinced that agile methods can be used profitably and can motivate others to do so.
Self-organization
The ability to organize oneself and manage tasks
Participants are familiar with the concepts of self-organization.
Participants understand how the concepts of self-organization influence their everyday work
Participants are able to work on projects, processes and tasks in a self-organized manner.
Participants are able to work on projects, processes and tasks in a self-organized manner.
Communication & collaboration

The ability to communicate constructively, efficiently and consciously, including across domains, while recognizing and taking into account the feelings of other people and shaping relationships with colleagues and superiors sustainably and fairly.
Participants know the necessity of these skills
Participant recognizes and understands the relevance of this competence, especially with regard to the application of SE
Participants are able to communicate constructively and efficiently and at the same time be empathetic towards their communication partner.
Participant is also able to manage their relationships with colleagues and superiors in a sustainable and fair way
Leadership

The ability to select suitable goals for a system or system element, to negotiate when necessary and to achieve them efficiently with a team and, if necessary, to guide team members in solving problems.
Participants know the necessity of these skills
Participant understands the relevance of defining goals for a system and can define them in a way that is understandable for the entire team
Participant is able to negotiate goals with the team and find an efficient way to achieve them.
Participant is able to strategically develop team members so that they continue to develop when finding solutions
Project management
The competence to identify, plan, coordinate and adapt activities to deliver a satisfactory system, product or service with appropriate quality, finances and time.

Process: The participant is familiar with thematic field project management and can organize their activities in a project planMethod: The participant knows the common methods of project management.Tool: The participant understands why a tool is used for project management.

Process: The participant understands the project assignment and can categorize project management in the context of system engineering.Methods: The participant can independently create the (project) plans relevant to him and generate corresponding status reports (with regard to Q-K-T).Tool: The participant is able to carry out planning in the respective tool.

Process & Method: The participant is able to define a project assignment and set framework conditions, create complex project plans and generate meaningful reports. The participant is practiced in communicating with stakeholders. 
Tool: The participant is able to carry out planning in the respective tool.

Process: The participant is able to identify shortcomings in the process and make suggestions for improvement. He is able to successfully communicate reports, plans and orders to all stakeholders.
Tool: Participants can use advanced functions and create templates.
Decision management
The ability to identify, characterize and evaluate an objective set of alternatives in a structured and analytical manner, taking risks and opportunities into account
Participants know the main decision-making bodies and how decisions are made
Participants learn about decision support methods and understand which decisions they can make themselves and which are made by Gremine etc.
Participants are able to prepare decisions for their relevant scopes or make them themselves and document them accordingly. They can apply methods of decision support (e.g. utility analysis).
Participants can evaluate decisions and are able to define and establish overarching decision-making bodies. They can define good guidelines for making decisions.
Information management
The ability to address all aspects of information for specific stakeholders in order to deliver the right information at the right time and with the right level of certainty.
The participant knows the advantages of established information and knowledge management.
The participant knows the main platforms for knowledge transfer and knows which information needs to be passed on to whom.

The participant knows the main platforms for knowledge transfer. They are able to define filing structures and documentation guidelines for projects and can make the relevant information available in the appropriate place.
The participant can define a comprehensive information management process.
Configuration Management
The ability to harmonize system functions, performance and physical characteristics over the lifecycle and ensure consistency.

process. The participant understands the necessity of configuration management
Tool: The participant knows in which tools configuration items are to be created.

Process: The participant understands the procedure for defining configuration items. He is able to recognize the configuration items relevant to him and to create an integer configuration for his relevant scopes.
Tool: The participant is able to create the tool(s) for his scopes

Process: The participant can define meaningful configuration items. He is able to recognize the configuration items relevant for him and to create an integer configuration for his relevant scopes.
Tool: The participant is able to define configuration items in the tool(s) and create them for his scopes

Process: He is able to recognize all relevant configuration items and build an integer configuration across all configuration items. He is able to identify improvements and propose solutions. He can support others in forming configurations.
Tool: The participant is able to define configuration items in the tool(s) and form a configuration for all scopes.
Implementation
The ability to realize a system, subsystem, component according to the specifications.

learning_objectives.col_1: Definition: A learning objective is a description of the state in which the participants find themselves at the end of the course/module in terms of competence, knowledge and qualifications.

learning_objectives.col_3: Example: At the end of the two-day course , the participants know all ten important product features and their benefits. They explain the features and benefits in a simulated customer discussion. This enables the participants to successfully complete the subsequent sales training.

They can roughly categorize them in the development process.Method: The participants know that there is a dedicated methodology and modeling language for architecture modeling.Tool: Participants know that there is a dedicated tool for viewing and, if necessary, editing architecture models.
learning_objectives.col_4: Process: Participants can understand why architecture models are relevant as inputs and outputs of the development process.Method: Participants can read architecture models and extract relevant information from them.Tool: Participants can view architecture models in a tool and comment on/review them.
learning_objectives.col_5: Process: Participants know the relevant process steps for architecture models and know where their inputs come from in the development process and what outputs they produce.Method: Participants can create architecture models of average complexity. They are able to reproduce relevant information in accordance with the method and modeling language.Tool: Participants can create and analyze architecture models in a tool.
learning_objectives.col_6: Process: Participants are able to recognize shortcomings in the process and develop suggestions for improvement.Method: Participants are able to create and manage models of high complexity. They can recognize shortcomings in the method or modeling language and develop suggestions for improvement.Tool: Participants can use advanced functions and create templates.
learning_objectives.col_7:
The architecture process in the company
Development of functional, logical architecture
Synthesis - deriving the physical architecture from the logical architecture
Assignment of requirements to the architecture incl. derivation of requirements
Further architecture views (security, safety, etc.)
Images of alternatives, selection of alternatives
Criteria for architectures (comparative studies)
Interfaces and interactions between system elements, external systems and peripheral systems
Relationship between functional and phys. elements

learning_objectives.col_2: The competence to integrate a set of system elements into a verifiable or validatable unit or to provide objective proof that a system fulfills the specified requirements (validation) or achieves its intended properties in the intended operating environment (validation).
learning_objectives.col_3: The participant knows the objectives of verification and validation and knows different types and procedures of V&V.
learning_objectives.col_4: The participant can read and understand test plans, test cases and test results.
learning_objectives.col_5: The participant can create test plans. They will be able to carry out and document tests and simulations.
learning_objectives.col_6: The participant is able to set up a test strategy and a test plan independently and at an early stage. Based on the requirements and verification/validation criteria, they will be able to derive the necessary test cases. They will be able to orchestrate and document the tests and simulations.
learning_objectives.col_7:
System integration strategies
Definition of IVV
Verification procedures (system, element, device)
Verification methods
Traceability to requirements
Validation procedures
Corrective actions
Validation methods
V&V in the phases of the life cycle (esp. early phase)
Final acceptance of the system

learning_objectives.col_2: The competence to commission and operate the system and maintain its capabilities/functionalities over its lifetime.
learning_objectives.col_3: The participants know the lines of the operation, service and maintenance phase. They know that these are already taken into account during development and that there are activities in the respective phase.
learning_objectives.col_4: Participants understand how the operation, service and maintenance phases are taken into account in development. They will be able to name the activities that are necessary in the life cycle.
learning_objectives.col_5: Participants understand how the operation, service and maintenance phases are taken into account in development. They will be able to process the phases and identify improvements for future projects.
learning_objectives.col_6: Participants will be able to define the organizational processes for operations, service and maintenance,
learning_objectives.col_7:
Operating strategies
Evaluation of operating data
Obtaining and evaluating user feedback
Recording performance data, error messages
Maintenance strategies
Consumables
Maintenance analyses
Continue and reuse
Deactivation, decommissioning
Disposal strategy

learning_objectives.col_2: The competence to apply methods that support the agile values in the project context and enable parallel work
learning_objectives.col_3: Method: The participant knows the agile values and the relevant agile methods
learning_objectives.col_4: Method: The participant understands the basics of agile working methods and how agile methods can be applied in a development process.
learning_objectives.col_5: Method: the participant can work in an agile environment. He is able to apply the necessary methods.
learning_objectives.col_6: The participant can define and implement the relevant agile methods for a project. The participant is convinced that agile methods can be used profitably and can motivate others to do so.
learning_objectives.col_7:
Scrum
SAFe

learning_objectives.col_2: The ability to organize oneself and manage tasks
learning_objectives.col_3: Participants are familiar with the concepts of self-organization.
learning_objectives.col_4: Participants understand how the concepts of self-organization influence their everyday work
learning_objectives.col_5: Participants are able to work on projects, processes and tasks in a self-organized manner.
learning_objectives.col_6: Participants are able to work on projects, processes and tasks in a self-organized manner.
learning_objectives.col_7:
Own behavior and personal characteristics
Time management, 
personal. Work organization

learning_objectives.col_2: The ability to communicate constructively, efficiently and consciously, including across domains, while recognizing and taking into account the feelings of other people and shaping relationships with colleagues and superiors sustainably and fairly.
learning_objectives.col_3: Participants know the necessity of these skills
learning_objectives.col_4: Participant recognizes and understands the relevance of this competence, especially with regard to the application of SE
learning_objectives.col_5: Participants are able to communicate constructively and efficiently and at the same time be empathetic towards their communication partner.
learning_objectives.col_6: Participant is also able to manage their relationships with colleagues and superiors in a sustainable and fair way
learning_objectives.col_7:
Stakeholder-oriented communication
Basics of communication techniques (4 pages,. Self-image, external image, Johari window (Joseph Luft, Harry Ingham))
Cooperation, personalities
Negotiation technique
Interpersonal communication
Socially competent behavior
Methods of conflict resolution and motivation
Feedback rules,. Active listening

learning_objectives.col_2: The ability to select suitable goals for a system or system element, to negotiate when necessary and to achieve them efficiently with a team and, if necessary, to guide team members in solving problems.
learning_objectives.col_3: Participants know the necessity of these skills
learning_objectives.col_4: Participant understands the relevance of defining goals for a system and can define them in a way that is understandable for the entire team
learning_objectives.col_5: Participant is able to negotiate goals with the team and find an efficient way to achieve them.
learning_objectives.col_6: Participant is able to strategically develop team members so that they continue to develop when finding solutions
learning_objectives.col_7:
Definition of team, team leadership
Phases of team development
Characters in a team (personality model (e.g. Riemann - Thomann), proximity versus distance, duration versus changes)
Characteristics and methods of team leadership
Situational leadership theory
Colloboration, special features and characteristics of a successful team
Leadership styles: (Hersey and Blanchard)

learning_objectives.col_2: The competence to identify, plan, coordinate and adapt activities to deliver a satisfactory system, product or service with appropriate quality, finances and time.
learning_objectives.col_3: Process: The participant is familiar with thematic field project management and can organize their activities in a project planMethod: The participant knows the common methods of project management.Tool: The participant understands why a tool is used for project management.
learning_objectives.col_4: Process: The participant understands the project assignment and can categorize project management in the context of system engineering.Methods: The participant can independently create the (project) plans relevant to him and generate corresponding status reports (with regard to Q-K-T).Tool: The participant is able to carry out planning in the respective tool.
learning_objectives.col_5:
Process & Method: The participant is able to define a project assignment and set framework conditions, create complex project plans and generate meaningful reports. The participant is practiced in communicating with stakeholders. 
Tool: The participant is able to carry out planning in the respective tool.
learning_objectives.col_6:
Process: The participant is able to identify shortcomings in the process and make suggestions for improvement. He is able to successfully communicate reports, plans and orders to all stakeholders.
Tool: Participants can use advanced functions and create templates.
learning_objectives.col_7:
Project goals and scope
PSP - Planning projects
Work packages
Schedule, budget plan, SE plan
Resources, roles, responsibilities
Release 
Project structure
Review milestones
Corrective measures and changes
Project completion
Determination of KPIs
Reporting
Evaluation

learning_objectives.col_2: The ability to identify, characterize and evaluate an objective set of alternatives in a structured and analytical manner, taking risks and opportunities into account
learning_objectives.col_3: Participants know the main decision-making bodies and how decisions are made
learning_objectives.col_4: Participants learn about decision support methods and understand which decisions they can make themselves and which are made by Gremine etc.
learning_objectives.col_5: Participants are able to prepare decisions for their relevant scopes or make them themselves and document them accordingly. They can apply methods of decision support (e.g. utility analysis).
learning_objectives.col_6: Participants can evaluate decisions and are able to define and establish overarching decision-making bodies. They can define good guidelines for making decisions.
learning_objectives.col_7:
Decision strategy
Evaluation of alternatives
Recording the decisions
Risk profiles
Risk identification
Dealing with risks (planning, measures)
Preventive measures
Technological classification Project

learning_objectives.col_2: The ability to address all aspects of information for specific stakeholders in order to deliver the right information at the right time and with the right level of certainty.
learning_objectives.col_3: The participant knows the advantages of established information and knowledge management.
learning_objectives.col_4: The participant knows the main platforms for knowledge transfer and knows which information needs to be passed on to whom.
learning_objectives.col_5: The participant knows the main platforms for knowledge transfer. They are able to define filing structures and documentation guidelines for projects and can make the relevant information available in the appropriate place.
learning_objectives.col_6: The participant can define a comprehensive information management process.
learning_objectives.col_7:
Communication planning 
Information distribution
Information storage

learning_objectives.col_2: The ability to harmonize system functions, performance and physical characteristics over the lifecycle and ensure consistency.
learning_objectives.col_3:
process. The participant understands the necessity of configuration management
Tool: The participant knows in which tools configuration items are to be created.
learning_objectives.col_4:
Process: The participant understands the procedure for defining configuration items. He is able to recognize the configuration items relevant to him and to create an integer configuration for his relevant scopes.
Tool: The participant is able to create the tool(s) for his scopes
learning_objectives.col_5:
Process: The participant can define meaningful configuration items. He is able to recognize the configuration items relevant for him and to create an integer configuration for his relevant scopes.
Tool: The participant is able to define configuration items in the tool(s) and create them for his scopes
learning_objectives.col_6:
Process: He is able to recognize all relevant configuration items and build an integer configuration across all configuration items. He is able to identify improvements and propose solutions. He can support others in forming configurations.
Tool: The participant is able to define configuration items in the tool(s) and form a configuration for all scopes.
learning_objectives.col_7:
Configuration item
Create configurations 
Configuration control
Configuration control cycle (V&V, evaluation, release)
Configuration documentation
baselines
change management
